Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task has generous buffer time and others can proceed without it for a while.
Expectation2: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation2: An emergency motion for a temporary restraining order has just been filed, requiring you to immediately review the documents and make a ruling within the hour.
Story: I was at my desk, halfway through the report my team needed by Friday. As a colleague, I knew I was expected to finish my part on time, but with the generous buffer, I’d planned to take my time and double-check everything. My phone buzzed—a notification from the court clerk. An emergency motion for a temporary restraining order had just landed on my docket. As a judge, I was expected to drop everything, review the case files thoroughly, and make a ruling within the hour. My mind raced. If I shifted focus now, I’d lose my momentum on the report and risk letting my team down, even if the deadline wasn’t pressing. But the urgency of the motion weighed on me; someone’s safety could depend on my immediate attention. I stared at the two stacks of papers on my desk, feeling the pressure of both roles squeezing in on me, each demanding my full attention, each with its own consequences if I failed. My hands hovered over the files, heart pounding, torn between the expectations of my colleagues and the gravity of my judicial responsibility.
